;周二，巴西总统提议创建一种区域贸易货币来与美元抗衡他主持了一次区域峰会，以期重振南美洲 12 个政治两极分化国家的集团。

;

;南美国家联盟 (Unasur) 于 2008 年成立以促进合作，但后来基本上已不复存在大约十年后，在领导权纠纷中。当时领导人右倾的国家——包括巴西——认为该集团有左倾倾向，并特别反对委内瑞拉的独裁左翼总统尼古拉斯·马杜罗加入。

;

;巴西新任左翼总统路易斯·伊纳西奥·卢拉达鉴于该地区有更多的左翼和中间派领导人，席尔瓦提议重启欧盟。他在巴西利亚召集了南美峰会，除了一位总统外，该地区的所有总统都出席了会议。

;

;在开幕词中，卢拉表示，该集团应该讨论创造一种货币来挑战美元霸权，因为以及共同的能源市场和该地区国防与安全的整合。

;

;“只要我们不团结，我们就不会使南美洲成为一个充分发挥其潜力的发达大陆，”卢拉说.

;

;1 月份上任的前工会会员卢拉在峰会前的周一首次双边会谈中欢迎马杜罗。他批评美国等国家为让委内瑞拉实现政治自由化而实施的经济制裁，称其“完全夸大其词”。

;

;卢拉表示，“让委内瑞拉成为主权国家一次”取决于马杜罗再次。我们的对手将不得不为他们造成的损害道歉。”

;

;卢拉的前任、右翼民粹主义者雅伊尔·博尔索纳罗 (Jair Bolsonaro) 追随其他右倾领导人的脚步，将巴西从 Unasur 中拉了出来2019 年。卢拉的一个关键优先事项是重建与在博尔索纳罗统治下断绝的地区邻国的关系。

;

;博尔索纳罗下令就巴西骚乱接受质询

;

;Pablo Ibanez，他任教里约热内卢联邦农村大学的地缘政治学教授表示，卢拉迫切需要修复与委内瑞拉的关系，部分原因是两国有共同边界，而且需要处理委内瑞拉移民和难民问题。

;

;但卢拉很热情Ibanez 说，周一对马杜罗的欢迎被巴西领导人称为“历史性的”，这可能走得太远了，并有可能使南美集团其他成员之间的紧张局势再度升级。

;

;“巴西政府提供了大量弹药反对派团体，”Ibanez 说。

;

;包括卢拉和马杜罗在内的 11 位南美总统将出席此次峰会，还有秘鲁部长会议的领导人，总统迪娜博卢阿尔特在会议上面临

;

;政治分析人士说，由于该地区现任政府的政治亲和力，卢拉感觉到了融合的机会，但他们表示，要让欧盟在该地区的政治危机中幸存下来将是一个挑战

;

;咨询公司 Polilat 的阿根廷主管豪尔赫·阿里亚斯 (Jorge Arias) 表示，巴西将寻求在当前的一体化倡议上“打上较​​少意识形态的印记”，以实现某种程度的团结，并努力确保其持久.

;

;虽然大多数南美现任总统都是左派或中间派，但不能保证情况会一直如此。今年 5 月，智利右翼分子在投票选举委员会成员以编写新宪法时取得了成功，这突显了这一点。鉴于现任总统阿尔贝托·费尔南德斯今年不会在通货膨胀猖獗的情况下寻求连任，阿根廷也可能出现类似的右倾趋势。

;

;这表明南美领导人的想法各不相同。 , 哥伦比亚左翼总统古斯塔沃·佩特罗告诉记者，周二的会议可以通过制定债权国为债务国提供债务减免以换取其减少碳排放承诺的制度来促进气候变化方面的进展。

;耻辱的 Theranos 首席执行官伊丽莎白霍姆斯被关押在得克萨斯州监狱，她可以在那里度过根据美国联邦监狱局的说法，监督血液检测骗局成为硅谷贪婪和狂妄自大寓言的 11 年。

;

;周二，39 岁的福尔摩斯进入了位于在得克萨斯州布赖恩——去年 11 月判处福尔摩斯的联邦法官建议将她监禁。最低安全设施位于休斯敦西北约 150 公里（93 英里）处，福尔摩斯在那里长大，立志成为 Apple 联合创始人史蒂夫乔布斯的技术梦想家。

;

;当她开始她的句子时，福尔摩斯留下了两个年幼的孩子——一个儿子出生于 2021 年 7 月，在她的审判开始前几周，还有一个三个月大的女儿，她是在陪审团于 2022 年 1 月判定她犯有四项欺诈和共谋重罪后怀上的。

;

;福尔摩斯自此获得保释，最近与孩子的父亲威廉“比利”埃文斯一起住在圣地亚哥地区。这对夫妇于 2017 年相识，当时 Holmes 因 Theranos 的倒闭而接受调查，这是她在 19 岁时从斯坦福大学辍学后创办的一家初创公司。

;

;当时她正在建立 Theranos , Holmes 与 Ramesh，“Sunny” Balwani 的关系越来越密切，后者将成为她的浪漫伴侣，以及加利福尼亚州帕洛阿尔托公司的投资者和同事。

;

;Holmes 和 Balwani 共同承诺 Theranos 将通过一项技术彻底改变医疗保健，这种技术可以通过刺破手指采集几滴血来快速扫描疾病和其他问题。

;

;围绕这一据称突破的炒作帮助 Theranos 从吸引的投资者那里筹集了近 10 亿美元，组建了一个有影响力的董事会，其中包括前总统内阁成员乔治·舒尔茨、亨利·基辛格和詹姆斯·马蒂斯，并使福尔摩斯在 2014 年成为硅谷的轰动人物，其账面财富价值 45 亿美元。

;

;但它在 Theranos 技术的严重危险缺陷被 Holmes 和 Balwani 试图阻挠的《华尔街日报》上的一系列爆炸性文章曝光后，所有这些都被炸毁了。

;

;Theranos 前总裁 Balwani 被判犯有欺诈罪

; h3>;

;Holmes 和 Balwani 在经营 Theranos 时一直秘密同居，但在《华尔街日报》的揭露和公司倒闭后分手了。 2018 年，美国司法部指控两人犯有一系列白领罪行，目的是制止硅谷过度销售一项仍在开发的技术的能力的做法——这种技术后来被称为“假冒” 'til you make it”。

;

;Holmes 承认在 Theranos 犯了错误，但在她受审期间在证人席上作证的 7 天（通常令人着迷的证词）期间坚决否认犯下罪行。有一次，她告诉陪审团她遭到 Balwani 的性虐待和情感虐待，而 Balwani 控制她的方式使她的思想蒙上了阴影。 Balwani 的律师坚决否认 Holmes 的指控，这是他们分别受审的主要原因之一。

;

;Balwani，57 岁，在 Holmes 被指控两个月后开始的审判中被判犯有 12 项欺诈和共谋重罪。结束了。他目前在南加州监狱服将近 13 年的刑期。

;

;霍尔姆斯坚称她在审判期间受到不公平对待，在对定罪提出上诉时寻求保持自由。但这一提议被主持她审判的美国地区法官爱德华达维拉和第九巡回上诉法院拒绝，使她别无选择，只能在她创立 Theranos 近 20 年后将她送进监狱。 .

;

;在周二美联社联系福尔摩斯的代表律师发表声明时，他们没有立即做出回应。

;

;FPC Bryan 占地约 37 英亩，居住着约 650 名女性，其中包括 Real Housewives盐湖城明星詹妮弗·沙阿 (Jennifer Shah) 今年早些时候因在长达数年的电话营销骗局中欺骗数千人而被判处 6.5 年监禁。

;

;大多数联邦监狱营地甚至没有围栏和房屋监狱局认为安全风险最低的那些。监狱营地的工作人员通常也很少，许多被关押在那里的人在监狱工作。

;

;根据 2016 年 FPC 布莱恩囚犯手册，得克萨斯州设施中有资格工作的人可以赚到 12他们在工作分配中每小时支付 1.15 美元和 1.15 美元，其中包括食品服务角色和由 Federal Prison Industries 经营的工厂就业。

;

;在 Theranos 为 Elizabeth Holmes 工作是什么感觉？

;

;联邦监狱营地最初的设计安全性较低，目的是让操作更容易，并让负责在监狱执行工作（如景观美化和维护）的囚犯避免反复进出主要监狱设施。

;

;但松懈的安全措施为毒品、手机和武器等违禁品打开了大门。有限的安全措施也导致许多人逃离监狱营地。

;

;11 月，一名被关押在亚利桑那州另一个联邦监狱营地的男子在探视区掏出一把走私的枪，并试图射杀他的妻子

;

;枪卡壳了，没有人受伤。但该事件暴露了该设施的重大安全漏洞，该机构的负责人下令对美国各地所有联邦监狱营地的安全进行审查。

;前第一夫人罗莎琳·卡特 (Rosalynn Carter) 的家人宣布，她患有痴呆症，目前仍在家中。

;

;现年 95 岁的卡特与前总统吉米·卡特一起留在家中，后者自今年年初以来一直在家中接受临终关怀。

;

;她的丈夫，在平原享受春天，探望亲人，”这家人通过卡特中心说，卡特中心是这对夫妇离开白宫后于 1982 年成立的全球人道主义组织。

;

;结婚近 77 年，卡特是美国历史上结婚时间最长的第一对夫妇。

;

;该家族在声明中指出，罗莎琳·卡特 (Rosalynn Carter) 在其漫长的公共生活中一直致力于为受精神疾病影响的个人和家庭以及那些与亲人保持照料关系的人发声.

;

;“卡特夫人经常说，这个世界上只有四种人：一直照顾的人；那些目前是看护者、那些将成为看护者和那些将需要看护者的人，”声明中写道。

;

;98 岁的美国前总统吉米·卡特在家中接受“临终关怀”

;

;“看护的普遍性在我们家庭中显而易见，我们正在体验这段旅程的快乐和挑战。我们不希望进一步发表评论，并请求理解我们的家人以及全国各地担任护理人员角色的每个人。”

;

;近几个月来，卡特一家只与家人和密友一起探望，之后前总统宣布他将在一系列短期住院后放弃进一步的医疗干预。

;1964 年 8 月 4 日，美国声称北越巡逻艇袭击了美国海军驱逐舰马多克斯在东京湾。这导致美国国会在不到一周后通过了北部湾决议，成为时任总统林登约翰逊向南越派遣美军的合法理由。这导致美国公开卷入越南内战。

;

;我们现在知道，袭击从未发生，重大决定是基于海军情报，根据约翰逊的政治需要和偏好调整的。他正在寻找借口在国会没有正式宣布的情况下将国家发动战争。那是那时。但历史总是会重演，尤其是如果不吸取教训的话。

;

;最近的事态发展是否可以为美军介入其他国家的冲突提供借口——这一次是在菲律宾和中国之间南中国海？这样的事件可能 - 像以前一样 - 将美国盟友澳大利亚和韩国卷入更广泛的争端。

;

;这种情况的一个版本可能发生在仁爱礁，中国海岸警卫队最近阻止了一艘菲律宾海岸警卫队船只进入接近浅滩。根据在《联合国海洋法公约》主持下成立的国际仲裁小组，该浅滩是菲律宾大陆架的一部分，并在其专属经济区内。

;

;因此，菲律宾，对其资源拥有专属主权。从技术上讲，任何国家都不能对淹没的地物宣称拥有主权。然而，菲律宾将其视为主权问题。中国还声称这是其对南中国海大部分地区的历史性主张的一部分，但被同一专家组驳回。因此，这场争端带有民族主义色彩，不采取行动可能会威胁到两国政府的合法性。

;

;对最近的近乎碰撞的指责并不像大多数西方媒体所描述的那样非黑即白。北京表示，这一事件是马尼拉有预谋的挑衅。是的，资源属于菲律宾，中国船只挡住了菲律宾同行的航道，违反了国际公约。

;

;但菲律宾可能是想挑起事端。两艘菲律宾海岸警卫队船只公布了进入浅滩的意图，并警告中国船只“远离我们的通道”。马尼拉从以往的经验中知道，中国将对此做出积极反应。但它可能想煽动中国对顺应邀请参加其“主权巡逻”的国际记者作出回应，作为宣传中国掠夺行为的一部分。

;

;奇怪的是，这起事件恰好涉及菲律宾船只不携带记者，让他们在没有直接危险的情况下进行观察。记者适时炒作。

;

;但这与美国有什么关系？它与菲律宾签订了共同防御条约，如果对方受到攻击，则需要正式考虑提供军事帮助。此前美国国务院在“攻击”的含义上含糊其词，现在似乎向中国提出了挑战。

;

;现在“重申在包括南中国海在内的太平洋地区发动武装袭击，在菲律宾武装部队、公共船只或飞机上，包括海岸警卫队，将援引美国根据 1951 年《菲律宾共同防御条约》第四条做出的共同防御承诺。

;

;此外，美国指挥官太平洋舰队海军上将塞缪尔·帕帕罗表示，如果中国干涉马尼拉为停泊在浅滩上的海军舰艇补给部队的努力，美国准备帮助菲律宾。

;

;美国一直在向菲律宾发出一般性警告中国关注此类行动已有一段时间了。到目前为止，包括激光照射菲律宾海岸警卫队舰桥在内的事件尚未触发美国启动防御条约的门槛。此外，在提供军事援助的要求方面也有回旋余地。

;

;条约第四条规定，对任何一方的武装攻击都将根据其宪法程序采取行动，并且应将其提交立即引起联合国安理会的注意。一旦安理会恢复和平与安全，敌对行动就必须停止。

;

;因此决策过程可能会被拖延，军事援助也得不到保证。然而，美国似乎在今年晚些时候同意与菲律宾联合巡逻，从而提高了赌注。第一个很可能在仁爱礁附近。

;

;南中国海的爆发点正在成倍增加。中国会怎么做？

;

;美国已经对自己产生了公众压力，要求其兑现其威胁。否则，就会失去信誉，被认为是没牙的老虎。这可能会导致中国误判。这种情况即将成为美国和中国之间的一场斗鸡游戏，菲律宾处于中间位置，甚至可能是调解人。

;

;如果双方都不先眨眼，可能会发生冲突。为了试图遏制冲突，美国很可能会使用海岸警卫队船只进行任何联合巡逻——而不是美国海军，因为美国海军和中国海军一样，将潜伏在地平线上。任何冲突是否加剧和蔓延取决于领导人的智慧。

;

;我乐观地认为一方或双方都会退缩。但是，考虑到华盛顿的反华情绪，像东京湾这样的事件——无论是真实的还是制造的——可能会促使国会要求采取军事行动。抓紧你的帽子。

;官员们表示，莫斯科没有人受重伤，住宅楼也只有“轻微”损坏，但一些普通民众表示，他们从未想过俄罗斯首都会受到这样的袭击。

;

;“我以某种方式认为所有这一切都在遥远的地方，这不会影响我们，突然间它变得非常近，”养老金领取者 Tatyana Kalinina 在莫斯科西南部一栋受损住宅楼附近说道.

;

;俄罗斯国防部表示，袭击中使用了 8 架无人机，并补充说其中 5 架被击落，3 架被击落。

;

;普京表示，莫斯科的防空系统在令人满意的方式，并指出这些袭击是基辅对俄罗斯袭击乌克兰军队情报总部的“回应”。他说，乌克兰正试图“吓唬”俄罗斯人。

;

;“我们谈到了打击指挥中心（在乌克兰），”俄罗斯总统说。

;

;“作为回应，基辅政权选择了一条不同的道路，试图恐吓俄罗斯、恐吓俄罗斯公民和袭击住宅建筑的道路。”

;

;乌克兰的无人机战争是如何演变的

;

;Of在击中住宅楼的三架无人机中，两架坠毁在莫斯科富裕的西南部的高层建筑中，而第三架则损坏了郊区的一栋住宅楼。

;

;其他无人机落在莫斯科郊外。一些碎片是在距普京的新奥加廖沃住所 15 公里（9 英里）处发现的。

;

;社交媒体上分享的一段视频显示，爆炸后一股浓烟冲天而起。

;

;本月，两架无人机在克里姆林宫上空被拦截，但周二的袭击是无人驾驶飞行器首次袭击距离乌克兰前线数百公里的莫斯科居民区。

;

;袭击是这可能被视为克里姆林宫的一大尴尬，克里姆林宫竭尽全力表示乌克兰旷日持久的冲突不会对俄罗斯人构成威胁。

;

;Mykhailo Podolyak，乌克兰总统 Volodymyr Zelensky 的顾问，说基辅与袭击“没有直接关系”。

;

;莫斯科市长谢尔盖·索比亚宁说，两人已经寻求医疗帮助，但“没有人受重伤”。

;

;居民在空袭中受损的建筑物被短暂疏散。

;

;梅德韦杰夫认为乌克兰战争将持续数十年，因为美国将军怀疑俄罗斯的胜利

;

;在 Profsoyuznaya 街，一栋窗户被炸毁的住宅楼被警察封锁，但气氛平静，孩子们在外面玩耍，当地人在遛狗。

;

;一些居民被转移到附近的学校，在那里他们喝茶，看苏联时代的电影.

;

;住在同一条街但更靠近莫斯科市中心的 50 岁 IT 工作者 Valentin Yemelyanov 说“没有恐惧或恐慌”。

;

;“损害很小，”他说。他说，鉴于冲突升级，他对无人机袭击“并不感到惊讶”。 “很明显，事情正朝着这个方向发展。”

;

;莫斯科人告诉俄罗斯记者，一架无人机也坠毁在 Leninsky Prospekt 一座高层建筑 14 层的公寓中，但没有爆炸。< /p>;

;在莫斯科郊区，40 岁的海关官员马克西姆说，凌晨 4 点，他和他的妻子被巨响吵醒了。他说他有一些与安全相关的问题要问当局，包括“为什么俄罗斯的边界仍然开放”。

;

;政治分析家塔蒂亚娜·斯塔诺瓦亚说，令人惊讶的是，俄罗斯当局“淡化了无人机袭击俄罗斯城市”。

;

;自俄罗斯开始攻击乌克兰以来，无人机袭击了莫斯科以外的目标，包括远离前线的军事设施。

;

;乌克兰首都防御俄罗斯在两天内进行第二次空袭

;

;乌克兰表示已击落 31 架无人机中的 29 架，主要是在俄罗斯最新的炮击中飞越基辅和基辅地区——24 小时内第三次击落乌克兰首都。< /p>;

;周一，俄罗斯向基辅发射了一连串导弹，导致惊慌失措的居民在夜间袭击后的一次不寻常的白天袭击中逃往避难所。

;

;可以预见的是，乌克兰的许多人对无人机袭击幸灾乐祸

;

;基辅市长 Vitali Klitschko 表示，他无法理解为什么当俄罗斯军队“恐吓”乌克兰首都时，莫斯科居民仍然过着和平的生活。他说，莫斯科人应该感受到“生活在基辅过去一年半的条件下意味着什么”。

;

;基辅一直在准备反攻，尽管它的时机和重点一直是几个月来猜测的主题。

;周日上海和北京之间的首次商业航班被视为中国竞标的关键一步

;“首航的完成将……推动客机生产的整个供应链——从设计、制造、培训和中国国际金融公司分析师陈贤凡周一表示。

;

;中泰证券在 7 月份估计，C919 的市场潜力将达到 1.36 万亿元人民币（192 美元）亿），加上其工业供应链的其他增值部分。

; Wed, 31 May 2023 00:20:02 +0800 How drone warfare has evolved in Ukrainehttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/russia-central-asia/article/3222352/how-drone-warfare-has-evolved-ukraine?utm_source=rss_feed

;;

;从带着相机和手榴弹在前线战壕上空嗡嗡作响的小型四轴飞行器到拖着炸弹飞行重达数十公斤的弹头进入基辅和莫斯科，无人机使乌克兰战争成为前所未有的标志。

;

;最近几个月，入侵的俄罗斯军队在基辅和其他主要城市，而乌克兰在克里米亚和俄罗斯边境地区别尔哥罗德发动了自己的无人袭击。

;

;俄罗斯政府周二甚至指责乌克兰用此类设备袭击莫斯科。

;

;今天的照片与战争初期围绕土耳其制造的 Bayraktar TB2 无人机的炒作相去甚远。

;

;这架飞机成为头条新闻，并因其在粉碎莫斯科装甲纵队和黑海舰队旗舰莫斯科号。

;

;但随着冲突的持续，这种被称为 MALE（中等高度、持久耐用）的型号已经失去了相关性。

;

;“前线一位不愿透露姓名的欧洲国防工业消息人士称，由于俄罗斯部署了“防御空中攻击的系统”，因此已经稳定下来并变得坚不可摧。

;

;现在无人机战争已成为一场数字游戏。

;

;大多数自杀式无人机都被防空系统击落，“用来迫使防御者发射导弹并耗尽储备”，一位法国高级军方消息人士说。

;

;“你也会在空中制造恐怖和不确定性一直。从长远来看，这是有价值的，”该消息人士补充道。

;

;分析师杰克·沃特林 (Jack Watling) 认为，俄罗斯的远程导弹产量限制在每月 40 枚左右，因此以低廉的成本削弱敌方防空系统尤为重要和英国国防智库 RUSI 的尼克·雷诺兹 (Nick Reynolds) 在最近的一份报告中写道。

;

;莫斯科空军“发射了大量飞机，以增加潜在威胁轴线的数量……[并]确定乌克兰空军的差距他们说，传统导弹可以通过的防空系统。

;

;基辅还使用“商用的中国螺旋桨动力无人机或老式苏联喷气动力侦察无人机”，可以攻击“俄罗斯境内”，欧洲工业消息人士称。

;

;绝大多数无人机都是在前线用于侦察和攻击的小型无人机。

;

;乌克兰军队在社交媒体上发布了许多视频，展示经过修改的无人机商用无人机向俄罗斯士兵的阵地投掷炸弹。

;

;在任何 10 公里长的前线，“两侧通常有 25 到 50 架无人机（无人驾驶飞行器） ”，RUSI 的 Watling 和 Reynolds 写道。

;

;专门建造的乌克兰 Furia 和俄罗斯 Eleron-3 无人机的航程可达 50 公里，而经过改装的商用四轴飞行器（许多是通过众筹购买的）的航程不到 10 公里。

; p>;

;蜂群迫使双方部署电子防御系统，降低了对抗设备的成本，这些设备太便宜了，不值得用昂贵的导弹击落。

;

;俄罗斯军队“现在部署了大约一个主要的每 10 公里正面的电子战系统”，根据 RUSI 的说法，“更专业的电子战能力”进一步提升了指挥链。

;

;“俄罗斯人已经加强了他们的电子战游戏。这是一个巨大的变化，”这位法国高级军官说。

;

;RUSI 说，即使是个别的俄罗斯排现在也配备了反无人机武器，包括“用于劫持无人机的定向干扰机和阵列”。

;

;欧洲行业消息人士称，发射干扰信号的反无人机“步枪”是“绝对的防御基础，真正起作用的是部署在前线附近的非便携式干扰器”。

;

; But such “big spheres on tripods with generators” are “easily spotted and have a limited life expectancy”, they added.

;

;Drone and anti-drone warfare were “a new form of combined arms combat”, the French officer said.

;

;“Just as we have infantry, cavalry and artillery, so we have drones, electronic warfare and connectivity.”

;

;With so much energy going into their destruction, most small drones “won't fly more than four or six times before being shot down”, the officer added.

;

;Ukraine has said they are losing around 10,000 drones per month across the large range of devices they use – a figure impossible to verify that could be aimed at securing more Western aid.

;

;If breakthroughs and counteroffensives see a return to rapidly shifting front lines, drones will remain relevant.

;

;Ukraine could use drones to clear Russian defensive barriers in its widely trailed summer attack, for instance “to drop explosives into a minefield, literally blowing a path through”, Vikram Mittal, a professor at US military academy West Point, wrote in Forbes.

;

;Where highly mobile advancing troops get cut off, “drones could offer a method to resupply these units with the ammunition and other supplies necessary for them to continue their operations”, he added.

;The US on Tuesday imposed sanctions on 17 people and entities based in China and Mexico who it accused of enabling counterfeit, fentanyl-laced pill production, as the Biden administration seeks to stem imports of the deadly drug.

;

;The US Treasury Department in a statement said it slapped sanctions on seven entities and six people based in China, as well as one business and three people based in Mexico.

;

;It accused those targeted of being involved in the sale of pill press machines and other equipment used to impress counterfeit trade markings onto illicitly produced pills, often laced with fentanyl and destined for the United States.

;

;“Treasury's sanctions target every stage of the deadly supply chain fuelling the surge in fentanyl poisonings and deaths across the country,” the Treasury's Under Secretary for Terrorism and Financial Intelligence, Brian Nelson, said in the statement.

;

;“Counterfeit pills laced with fentanyl constitute a leading cause of these deaths, devastating thousands of American families each year. We remain committed to using all authorities against enablers of illicit drug production to disrupt this deadly global production and counter the threat posed by these drugs.”

;

;The rate of drug overdose deaths involving the synthetic opioid fentanyl more than tripled in the United States from 2016 through 2021, according to a report by the US Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) released earlier this month.

;

;Don't blame China for US opioid crisis, says ambassador

;

;Fentanyl is up to 50 times stronger than heroin and 100 times stronger than morphine, and has increasingly been mixed with other illicit drugs often with lethal results.

;

;The Biden administration has been pushing for action as US drug-related overdose deaths surpassed 100,000 in 2021, according to government estimates.

;

;Washington has been seeking greater help from Beijing in stemming the illicit flow of fentanyl “precursor” chemicals from China, but US officials have told Reuters that Chinese counterparts have been reluctant to cooperate as relations between the two countries have soured.

; Wed, 31 May 2023 00:20:02 +0800 In a contest of ‘unequals’, China pitches to build a multipolar worldhttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3221963/contest-unequals-china-pitches-build-multipolar-world?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.05.30 23:30;
;;

;While the leaders of the world's richest countries met in the Japanese city of Hiroshima and singled out China as a source of their concerns on issues from maritime claims and economic intimidation to human rights, China rolled out the red carpet for leaders from five Central Asian countries in Xian, a city that witnessed the peak of prosperity in China's imperial dynasties.

;

;The timing of the two-day China-Central Asia Summit in mid-May, which partially overlapped with the Group of Seven summit, underscored China's efforts to catch up with the United States as a global statesman in a battle for influence amid rising tensions between Beijing and Washington-led Western countries, analysts say.

;

;“The China-Central Asia Summit was a first. The G7 hosts, schedules and summits are mapped well in advance. It would be an extraordinary coincidence if the Central Asia summit wasn't planned as competition,” said George Magnus, a research associate at Oxford University's China Centre.

;

;G7 leaders vow to counter China's 'malign' economic practices

;

;In a communique released at its closing, the G7 industrial powers criticised China for its use of “economic coercion”, militarisation of the South China Sea and “interference activities” aimed at undermining the safety of diplomats, the integrity of democratic institutions and economic prosperity.

;

;The group – consisting of the US, the United Kingdom, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, and Japan, as well as the European Union – also urged Beijing to press Russia to stop its military aggression and withdraw its troops from Ukraine.

;

;At about the same time in Xian, Chinese President Xi Jinping called for the “brethren in Central Asia” to unite against attempts to divide them, and claimed “ethnic conflicts, religious strife and cultural divisions” were not the main theme of the region. He pledged to expand trade and economic cooperation, deepen connectivity and improve energy cooperation.

;

;Xi also promised to provide 26 billion yuan (US$3.7 billion) in development support for the Central Asian nations, while the leaders of Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan backed Chinese engagement at a time of economic stress and external pressures. Some of them are on the radar of the US and Europe for their role in shipping parts and components to Russia's war machine.

;

;“The symbolism of hosting one summit of like-minded developing countries and being the target of a richer economies summit emphasises global division. And acrimony,” Magnus said.

;

;But with India and Brazil – both members of BRICS, along with China, Russia and South Africa – and South Korea also attending the G7 as guest countries, the summits also showed “a comparison of unequals”, he said.

;

;“With [Ukrainian President Volodymyr] Zelensky showing up in Japan too, and Russia not being invited, the symbolism might not be all to China's liking. The G7 still matters a lot,” he said.

;

;Still, the relative economic strength of the G7, or what US national security adviser Jake Sullivan called “the steering committee of the free world”, has been declining.

;

;The group's share of global gross domestic product in nominal terms peaked at nearly 70 per cent in the late 1980s, but declined to under 45 per cent in 2021. In purchasing-power parity terms, the BRICS grouping – representing the fast-growing developing economies – overtook the G7's share for the first time in 2020, and the gap is expected to widen in the years to come, according to data from the International Monetary Fund.

;

;However, Russia's invasion of Ukraine - at Europe's doorstep – has galvanised the G7 and the West, analysts say.

;

;“This sense of cohesion within the G7 and the West on Russia will be long-lasting,” said Sourabh Gupta, a senior fellow at the Institute for China-America Studies in Washington.

;

;“On the other hand, I am sceptical that the China challenge will have a similar galvanising effect or reinvigorate the G7 grouping in the same way over the medium or longer term,” Gupta said. “There are, in fact, important conceptual gaps among the parties in how they seek to engage, manage as well as deter China.

;

;“These countries are no longer the facilitator of prosperity and motor of global economic growth that they used to be. Their ability to lead through power of attraction as well as endow valuable global public good is slowly fading, which will make it harder by the day to bring the rest, contrasted with the West, on board its agenda against Beijing.”

;

;By making a play in Central Asia during the G7 summit, China was also signalling the soft distancing of Western countries and the international community from the “no limits” characterisation of its ties with Russia, Gupta said.

;

;Xi and Russian President Vladimir Putin proclaimed a “no limits” partnership between their two countries during the Russian leader's Beijing visit in February last year, 20 days before Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Putin later acknowledged after another in-person meeting in September that Xi had expressed “questions and concern” over Ukraine. China's much-challenged stance on the war in Ukraine has exacerbated its diplomatic isolation.

;

;“The Central Asia summit is a perfect platform for China to project to the Central Asian republics and to the world that China embodies a new type of international relations – one that is based on a shared interest in political stability and economic prosperity and not one based on sanctions, punishments and coercion,” Gupta said.

;

;While China's global statesman ambition is welcome, Beijing's best course of action is to not tie itself too tightly to any specific coalition or bloc of countries, be it Russia or developing countries. Instead, Gupta said, Beijing should seek the best possible ties with amenable G7 players – most notably, the western European countries with the EU.

;

;“More than any other major player in today's international relations, Beijing has the most to lose by having the system degenerate into a bloc-based format,” he said.

;

;Li Lifan, a specialist on Russia and Central Asia at the Shanghai Academy of Social Sciences, said China aimed to give Central Asian countries “practical support” through financing and help in building hydropower stations, roads and railways, instead of plunging any country into “ideological confrontations”.

;

;“It's not totally up to China when to schedule the summit, as it must respect the agendas of the Central Asian countries,” Li said. “It's clear China wants to make itself heard in a battle for influence between China and the US-led West.”

;

;China had been adjusting its diplomatic approaches in the past few months, learning to dexterously play its own independent-minded game to be a global statesman, he said.

;

;“Timing is very important when you try for a diplomatic coup. China will be extremely cautious in brokering deals with other countries,” he said. “The focus of China's diplomacy remains to stabilise relations with countries in the Asia-Pacific region, such as the Asean members.”

;

;How energy is powering China's relationships with Central Asia

;

;China has been taking a more active role as a mediator in global affairs. Since February, China has come up with a proposal to end the war in Ukraine and brokered a truce between Iran and Saudi Arabia. The active diplomacy also included Xi's state visit to Russia, a phone call with Zelensky, sending a special envoy to Kyiv and visits from EU leaders, as well as Germany, France, Brazil, Singapore, Malaysia and Gabon. Beijing has even offered to mediate between Israel and Palestine, as part of its new Global Security Initiative.

;

;China wants to show the world that it seeks peace and development, while it blames the US for stoking “ideological confrontation” and bullying its enemies, according to Tom Miller, an analyst at Gavekal Dragonomics.

;

;At the heart of this frenetic diplomacy was China's bid to win leadership of the Global South, a term that lumps together most of the world outside North America, Europe and half a dozen rich states in the Asia-Pacific, Miller wrote in a note earlier this month.

;

;China is far more popular in the Global South than in the world's rich countries, where its reputation has nosedived in recent years. A report released in October last year by University of Cambridge researchers, combining data from 30 surveys covering 137 countries, found that 62 per cent of citizens in developing countries view China favourably, rising to 70 per cent among those who do not live in liberal democracies. Developing countries with high levels of trade and investment with China are the most enthusiastic about China, especially members of the Belt and Road Initiative.

;

;“In addition to wooing developing nations with promises of closer economic cooperation, it is now presenting itself as a model for them to emulate. It also hopes to exploit a common desire across much of the Global South for a bigger say in global affairs, as it seeks to loosen the West's grip on international organisations,” Miller wrote.

;

;“But while China is making some progress in its bid to build a multipolar world, few countries will throw in their all with it, as it remains in their best interests to hedge between the rival superpowers.”

; Tue, 30 May 2023 23:50:02 +0800 China’s national computing power network accepts first provinces as it moves to pool data centres to bolster infrastructurehttps://www.scmp.com/tech/article/3222336/chinas-national-computing-power-network-accepts-first-provinces-it-moves-pool-data-centres-bolster?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.05.30 23:00;
;;

;China's national computing power network has accepted its first batch of provinces as Beijing seeks to pool and build up national digital infrastructure despite increasingly limited access to advanced chips amid US-imposed trade restrictions.

;

;Data centres in southern Guangdong province and the southwestern provinces of Sichuan and Guizhou have been admitted to the “China Computing Net (C2NET)”, according to a report by government-backed newspaper Southern Daily that cited a Monday announcement at an industrial event in Shaoguan, Guangdong.

;

;The C2NET was unveiled by the government last May to better consolidate and allocate computing power.

;

;By pulling together regional resources, the network operates with a coordinated computing power of more than 3 exaflops, meaning the ability to perform 3 quintillion calculations per second, the report said. As a reference, the world's top supercomputer, the United States' Frontier system, can achieve a maximal performance of 1.2 exaflops, according to ranking agency TOP500.

;

;China's internet watchdog warns of risks from generative AI, other advanced tech

;

;Demand for computing power is skyrocketing thanks to the rising popularity of artificial intelligence (AI), and China is trying to ensure a sufficient supply of computing power to support the country's research and technological progress.

;

;“Computing power will become a type of utility like electricity that no matter where the supply is, one can pay to use it when there is demand for computing,” said Gao Wen, director of the Shenzhen-government-owned Peng Cheng Laboratory, which leads the C2NET project.

;

;Gao added that computing power is also key to developing large language models (LLMs), the technology used to train the AI-powered chatbot ChatGPT. “The combination of computing power, data and algorithms is the core of LLMs,” said Gao, according to domestic media outlet Caijing.

;

;Gao's perspective is in line with comments by prominent Chinese venture capitalist Lee Kai-fu, who said over the weekend that one of the most promising AI investment strategies is computing infrastructure.

;

;Computing power has now become a key factor for a country's technological growth, and the US has been restricting China's access to advanced chips in recent times. Historian Chris Miller, the author of Chip War, has stated that “the rivalry between the United States and China may well be determined by computing power”.

;

;For example, Nvidia's data centre chip the A100 was added to the US export control list in August 2022, meaning it is unlikely China will have access to Nvidia's GH200 super chip, its most powerful AI chip yet, which the chip maker said on Monday is now in full production.

;

;Amid global interest in AI and the development of LLMs sparked by OpenAI's ChatGPT, Chinese companies and research institutes including Baidu and Alibaba Group Holding have rushed to launch domestic alternatives. Alibaba owns the South China Morning Post.

;

;Chinese institutions have so far launched at least 79 LLMs with over 1 billion parameters, a measure of the size and complexity of a model. In comparison, OpenAI's GPT-3.5 model has 175 billion parameters. Data has not yet been disclosed on the parameters for the updated GPT-4 model.

;

;The C2NET project is part of China's ambitious “Eastern Data and Western Computing” plan to address regional imbalances in digital resources. The project was announced in February 2022 by four central government agencies, under which data gathered from more prosperous areas in eastern China will be sent to poorer yet more spacious western areas for processing and storage.

;

;Around 70 per cent of national demand for computing now comes from first-tier cities in China, located along the eastern and southern seaboard, Huang Hongbo, deputy general manager of CTYun, the cloud unit of state-owned telecoms operator China Telecom, said on Monday.

; Tue, 30 May 2023 23:20:02 +0800 High-powered think tank to boost Hong Kong’s socio-economic standing unveiled with aim to tap into national developmenthttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/3222356/high-powered-think-tank-boost-hong-kongs-socio-economic-standing-unveiled-aim-tap-national?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.05.30 22:20;
;;

;More than 50 top academics and business leaders with extensive experience of mainland China have been enlisted for a high-powered Hong Kong think tank set up to advise the chief executive on boosting the city's socio-economic standing in line with national development.

;

;The 56-strong team, unveiled on Tuesday, will also work in three expert groups – economic advancement, social development and research strategy – under the Chief Executive's Policy Group (CEPU), headed by Stephen Wong Yuen-chiu.

;

;“Hong Kong has gone from chaos to order and now is in the critical period of transiting from stability to prosperity,” city leader John Lee Ka-chiu said before the announcement.

;

;“I hope to be able to make up for the lost time in the shortest time possible and achieve results. I would like to formulate policies to bring positive values and impacts to Hong Kong in the short, medium and long term.”

;

;The think tank includes top figures from business, finance and the academic world, all appointed with immediate effect for a one-year term.

;

;The group also includes Chinese affairs expert Professor Zheng Yongnian. The Shenzhen-based academic is now presidential chair professor at the Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen.

;

;Zheng was among the experts invited in 2020 to share his views on the country's 14th five-year plan at a seminar hosted by Chinese President Xi Jinping in Beijing.

;

;He is a graduate of Peking University who went on to study at Princeton University in the United States and his advice is said to be often sought by senior central government figures.

;

;Zheng was also a director of the East Asian Institute at the National University of Singapore.

;

;Other major names on the expert group include Professor Lau Siu-kai, a consultant at the Beijing semi-official think tank, the Chinese Association of Hong Kong and Macau Studies; Adam Kwok Kai-fai, the executive director of Sun Hung Kai Properties; and Martin Lee Ka-shing, the chairman of Henderson Land Development.

;

;“To help Hong Kong integrate into national development, it is natural that the government needs to tap the expertise of those who know China and the Greater Bay Area initiative,” said Lau, also a former head of the government's Central Policy Unit.

;

;“If the CEPU can make good use of the experts as their mentors or resource persons, it can also help extend the CEPU's people connection and enhance the quality of their research.”

;

;More day trips for Hong Kong officials to Greater Bay Area to foster integration

;

;Lau added he understood the group was expected to meet once or twice a year.

;

;CEPU head Wong said all the members had significant experience and knowledge in their fields and were keen to offer their views and innovative ideas to benefit the city.

;

;Wong added that, in addition to the regular meetings of the new group, his unit would also consult appropriate members on specific areas to maximise use of their specialist skills.

;

;Chan Wai-keung, a Polytechnic University political scientist, agreed that the city government needed more experts on China to help it formulate policies to align with national development amid a difficult geopolitical environment.

;

;“Hong Kong-grown bureaucrats do not seem to understand China much,” Chan said.

;

;“Similar high-profile panels to advise the chief executive have also been formed in previous terms of the government. But not much seems to have been achieved. We just hope the expert group this time will not become just another talking shop.”

;

;Other academics and analysts recruited for the new think tank are Guo Wanda, an economist and executive vice-president of the Shenzhen-based China Development Institute and Professor Huang Ping, the director of the Centre for Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau Studies at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences.

;

;Hong Kong leader wraps up bay area trip hailing 'consensus' with 4 cities

;

;Experts from business include veteran investment banker Levin Wang Lei, the chief executive officer of Huatai Financial Holdings, the Hong Kong investment banking arm of Huatai Securities, the third-biggest brokerage in the mainland.

;

;Also signed up is the chief executive of China Development Bank's Hong Kong branch and Hong Kong Chinese Enterprises Association vice-chairman Li Xiguang.

;

;Hong Xiaoyuan, the non-executive director of China Merchants Bank Company and assistant to the president of China Merchants Group, and Dowson Tong Taosang, the senior executive vice-president of Tencent, a major tech and entertainment company, have also been recruited.

;

;Ma Jun, the chairman and president of the Hong Kong Green Finance Association who was chief economist at the People's Bank of China research bureau and chief economist for Greater China at Deutsche Bank, is also on board.

;

;Hong Kong, Guangdong cities cooperating will produce mutual gains: John Lee

;

;The government in March also announced the establishment of the chief executive's Council of Advisers. The council, made up of 34 members, is an advisory body for the city leader on the strategic development of Hong Kong.

;

;It also has three subgroups – economic advancement and sustainability, innovation and entrepreneurship, and regional and global collaborations.

;

;Council members include business leaders such as Victor Li Tzar-kuoi, Robert Ng Chee-isong, Peter Woo Kwong-ching, Allan Zeman, Guy Bradley, Victor Fung Kwok-king and Bernard Chan.
